# Elamite

[Download Linear-Elamite Font](http://files.pannous.com/Linear-Elamite.ttf)  

The closest living relative of Elamite may be [Brahui](Brahui.html)  

ğ’‡½ğ’‚Šğ’†·ğ’ˆ¬ğ’Œ‘ [LÃš] e-la-mu-Ãº [Leute] Elamites  

see [Elam](Elam.html) [Susa](Susa.html) ğœ’ ğœ‘°ğœ‚ SuÅ¡ina @ Iran  
see Medes  

Elamite cuneiform â‰ˆ 2200 BC replacing Proto-Elamite and Linear Elamite.

Elamite cuneiform appears to have used far fewer signs than its Akkadian prototype and initially relied primarily on syllabograms, but logograms became more common in later texts. Many signs soon acquired highly distinctive local shape variants that are often difficult to recognise as related to their Akkadian prototypes.

Linear Elamite is now (partly/almost) deciphered by Francois Desset and his team. Their recent [paper](https://www.sci-hub.ru/10.1515/za-2022-0003) lacks some of the great explanations and diagrams of earlier papers, it is highly recommended to read [these](https://www.academia.edu/search?q=desset) as well, and watch a seminar https://www.youtube.com/results?search_query=desset+elamite.  

![susa-egypt.png](susa-egypt.png)  
Near identical building plans of the early temples and very similar early Egyptian and Sumerian [ceremonies](Hieros-gamos) clearly demonstrate that these are not mere trade-artefacts, but in fact proof of a common anchestry of both higher civilizations. The connection with Susa is even stronger (cultic items, decimal numbers, â€¦).  

Before Elamite and Cuneiform diverged they had a very close semantic and pictographic correspondences:  

Both used Sexagesimal counting except for Animals and Slaves which were counted Decimal in Susa!  

ğ’†³ ğ’Š©ğ’†³ ğ’Š©  were near identical signs for workeslaves (ğ’Š© missed the ğ’¹ in Susa)  
ğ’‹¡ KA ğ“‚“  was combined with ğ’Š© and ğ’†³ in Susa and had a similar form (and meaning) in Uruk  
ğ’‡» ğ’ˆ§ ğ’ˆ¦ had a similar ğ’ˆ¦ sign for shee goats, ğ’‡» with horns appears in both (Susa round without ğ’ˆ¦)  
Vessels looked similar and were both combined with ğ’†³ and ğ’†œ KASKAL ğœ² ğœ³ ğœ´ cheese?  
ğ“Œ¸ ploughs [ğ’€³](ğ’€³.html) looked slightly similar to ğ“, as did arrows ğ’‹¾ (naturally)  
ğ’€­ signified a low-status human in early Susa! Maybe as (Â¬high)servant, or as ethnic contrast to Uruk? (vs ğ’ˆ¾!)  

High status humans in Susa are tentative, abstract and have no equivalent in Uruk, one is combined with an animal, one looks a bit like ğ”’´ another like ğ˜ƒğ“ˆ™ in a box  

Bisexagesimal numbering of grain products was similar  

Unfortunately these common number tablets are absent from egypt, so that details of the common anchestries divergence are lost.

# mesh gunu
In [Proto-Cuneiform](Proto-Cuneiform.html) and in Elamite gunu was often [realized as a mesh](httpwww.unicode.oL2020193-proto-cuneiform.pdf) similar to  
ğ’†œ KASKAL  
ğœ¤ ğœ¦ ğœ§ in ğœ“µ ğœ± ğœ² ğœ³ ğœ´ ğœ¯ ğœ° ğœ“»  
ğœ“… ğœš ğœ• ğœ” ğœ– ğœ™ ğœ˜ ğœ’¤  
ğœ’¥ ğœ‘¤ ğœ‘¥ ğœ‘¦ ğœ‘§ ğœ‘¨  
ğœ“ƒ ğœ‘† ğœ‘‡ ğœ‘ˆ ğœ‘…  
ğœ˜ ğœº  
ğœ  ğœ¿ ğœ½  
ğœ¢ ğœ€ ğœ¾  
ğœ¡ ğœ£ hal  
ğœ° ğœ ğœ¯ ğœ’ ğœ± ğœ²  
ğœ“š ğœ¶ ğœ·  
ğœ‘ ğœ‘ ğœ‘Ÿ ğœ‘  ğœ‘¡ ğœ‘¢ ğœ‘£  
ğœ“Œ ğœ“ ğœŠ  

different strokes and dots may have different significance.  

(Three) dots seem to be a simplified orthography for gunu!  
since these two signs were identified as variants: ğœ° ğœ“»  
Evidence is given by the [Indus](Indus.html) gunification of ğœ‹ ğœŒ ğœ– ğœ” (ğœ¢³ ğœ¢¹)  
In all these it is also accompanied by vertical mirroring!  
Also see ğœ° ğœ, but not ğœ° ğœ¯.  

The ğœ  nu might be a simplified ğœ§ gunu,  
However ğœ² and ğœ¯ have different reconstructed values, disproving that theory.  
Simplification of the gunu variants ğœ• ğœ”, ğœ‘¤ ğœ‘¥ may suggest a ğ’‰º P component, or is coincidental.

# Ligatures, connections and Variants
subtleties do matter, so be very careful with premature "identification" of characters  
Signs that look similar can be different and signs that look different on first sight can be homophones.  

??? What matters, what doesn't in clusters ???

Aus Postpositionen entwickelte Kasussuffixe gibt es erst in spÃ¤telamischer Zeit, die Ã¤lteren Sprachstufen unterscheiden einen Kasus nur beim Personalpronomen (Nominativ und Akkusativ, siehe unten). Einen Artikel gibt es nicht. Das Elamische ist keine Ergativsprache, fÃ¼r transitive und intransitive SÃ¤tze werden dieselben Subjektformen verwendet.  

Nominalphrasen haben immer die Reihenfolge Phrasenkopf - Attribut, wobei die Attribute Substantive (im Deutschen "Genitive"), Adjektive, Possessivpronomina und RelativsÃ¤tze sein kÃ¶nnen. Bis auf die RelativsÃ¤tze werden Attribute mit dem Phrasenkopf in der oben beschriebenen Art durch Kongruenzmarker verklammert.  


u (TITEL) B kuÅ¡i-h G1 ak G2 ap-u-i-n tuni-h  
"ich (TITEL) B baute-ich (kuÅ¡i-h), den GÃ¶ttern G1 und G2 - ihnen (ap) ich (u) es (i-n) - gab-ich (tuni-h)"  
"ich (TITEL) baute (Bauwerk) B und stiftete es den GÃ¶ttern G1 und G2"  

Die enklitische Partike markiert das Ende von Phrasen und SÃ¤tzen, satzeinleitende Partikel werden in den Ã¤lteren Sprachstufen nur selten verwendet.  


Alle Substantive werden im Elamischen zunÃ¤chst in zwei Hauptklassen (grammatische Geschlechter) eingeteilt, nÃ¤mlich der Personenklasse (PK) oder Sachklasse (SK).

5.5	VerbalstÃ¤mme  

Viele Wurzeln kÃ¶nnen im Elamischen nominal und verbal genutzt werden, z.B. me "RÃ¼ckseite" und "folgen", tu "Eigentum" und "nehmen". Die meisten VerbalstÃ¤mme enden auf einen Vokal, in den Ã¤lteren Sprachphasen gibt es auch konsonantischen Auslaut.  

Durch Reduplikation der Anlautsilbe kÃ¶nnen bei manchen Verben pluralisches Subjekt oder Objekt, aber auch "PluralitÃ¤t" der Handlung (also ihre Wiederholung) ausgedrÃ¼ckt werden (Steiner 1990, allerdings ist diese Interpretation nicht allgemein anerkannt). Dabei kann es zu lautlichen VerÃ¤nderungen kommen (z.B. Elision des Stammvokals). Einige Beispiele dieser Stammesmodifikationen durch Reduplikation der Anlautsilbe sind in der folgenden Tabelle zusammengestellt.

# Cuneiform Correspondences

Before Elamite and Cuneiform diverged they had a very close semantic and pictographic correspondences.  

Vague cuneiform form correspondences, direct or [complement](complement.html) (rotations etc)  

The phonetics may match without the semantics, or vice versa.  

Important to remember that all Akkadian signs as displayed in normal cuneiform fonts are rotated by 90Â°  

Rotation is already rampant in Linear Elamite, so weak matches are independent of orientation.  

Oftentimes an indirect connection can be established, despite graphic and phonetic divergence.  

Many signs have clear Egyptian counterparts without (used) cuneiform antagonists  ğœµ ğœ³ ğ“«  

# best matches
See "all matches" for complete analysis and explanation  

ğ’ƒ° GAN ubiquitous in Proto-Cuneiform and Proto-Elamite as ligature vessel is not identified yet.  
ğ’ƒ° GAN is similar to ğœ’£ sometimes, but sometimes left open. Maybe open form eradicated in simplification process.  
See [anatolian](anatolian.html) for open versus closed forms.

Syn & Sum  

Since this syllabary was certainly practised like our ABC, we might look into poetry with similar metric:  
5 morae  
Ì„ Ì† Ì„ cretic  
Ì† Ì„ Ì„ bacchius  
6 morae  
Ì„ Ì† Ì† Ì„ choriamb  
Ì† Ì† Ì„ Ì„ ionic (a minore)

ğœ… me  
The value me for is additionally confirmed by the fact that both the cuneiform Elamite syllable me (the suffix for abstract nouns) and the LE sign are optional in their actual use: cuneiform Elamite shows free variation between kuÅ¡ik-me u-me vs. kuÅ¡ik u-me â€œmy constructionâ€ or sunki-me u-me vs. sunki u-me â€œmy kingdom.â€ This pattern is reflected in LE sequences like vs. (MÃ¤der et al. 2018: tabs. 12â€“14).

# Numbers  
Numbers in Elamite are unknown. Candidates: ğœ“‚ ğœ“ƒ ğœ“„ ğœ“… ğœ“† ğœ“‡ ğœ“ˆ ğœ“‰ ğœ“Š ğœ“‹ ğœ“Œ ğœ“  
The Syllabary itself uses very Mesopotamian numbers though: 5 vowels * 12 consonants = 60 syllables the proven basis of Proto-Elamite number tablets. Speculation: The external 5 'heavenly' vowels and 12 alphabetic signs may correspond to the 5 planets and 12 months/zodiacs/gods. Sun and Moon dont fit in this schema exept for the extra 'zero' whole. 0â‰ˆÃ¸â‰ˆğ“‡³  

Counting sheep UDU. IDIM .MES ğ’‡»ğ’…‚ğ’ˆ¨ğ’Œ  Widder = "planets" ( Akkadian bibbu â‰ˆ ğ’…‚ )  

3  ğ’€¯ "Three Stars Each" per zodiac relevance?  
5  [planets](planets.html)  
6  work days (modern concept), important multiplier in Sexagesimal system!  
7  celestial bodies (planets, sun and moon)  
10  Decans (36 decans)  
12  dozen consonants (times two via ligature??)  
12  zodiacs ğ’€¯ star groups (3*4) not attested until 1000BC **  
12  year orbit of Jupiter along the ecliptic, used to define Babylonian zodiacs  
13  cursed number (mixing 12 consonants with holy vocal row)  
36  Egyptian decans form a year ( 6*6 / 3*12 / 3*10+6 )  
60  A bi-monthly period of 60 days (six decans) constitutes a half-[season](season.html) ( minutes in hour )  
100  ğ“…± ğ“² 10 decans, significance? counting ğ“…± Animals and Slaves.  
360 Six half-seasons + 5 gods constitute a year ( seconds in hour )  

** Sumerian or an Elamite(!) origin for these Babylonian constellations was proposed  

The best evidence for early Mesopotamian constellations and star names still remains with texts dated to the 2nd-millennium BCE (circa 1800 BCE). There is no evidence of any established system of any of astral omens or astronomy in the Sumerian sources. There are no cuneiform texts from the 3rd-millennium BCE containing records of astronomical observations. However, the eminent assyriologist Hermann Hunger ("The Cultic Calendars of the Ancient Near East." in The Journal of the American Oriental Society, October-December, 1996) states: "While there is no doubt that the sky was observed in Sumerian times for the purpose of omens and probably also in connection with cultic actions, this is not astronomy, which involves measuring and computing." Systematic astronomical observations are not indicated as being part of Sumerian tradition. Their cosmology contains mythic elements. The extent to which Sumerian myths related to astronomical objects i.e., planets, remains uncertain.

piá¹­Ätu  
Use of pÃ­, Egyptian archers  

The archers were part of the Egyptian army, and often requested by the Canaanite vassal city-states, when writing to the Pharaoh in the Amarna letters. They were named the pitati, Akkadian language "piá¹­Ätu",[6] "troops of soldiers", and spelled in a variety of ways, often starting with the bi sign as pÃ­.  

A partial listing of spellings of "ERIM.MEÅ -pitati", by Amarna letter:  

ğ“Šª ğ“ ğ“Šª ğ“ ğ“€œ | trample (enemies) | piÃ©tiner âˆšpod Æ¥otÆ¥ot 2-feet defeat / kaputt +++  
ğ“Šª ğ“ ğ“Šª ğ“ ğ“‚» | tread (roads), trample (enemies) | âˆšpod piÃ©tiner (kaput) +++  


The Shimashki or Simashki dynasty (ğ’ˆ—ğ’‚Šğ’‹›ğ’ˆ¦ğ’„€ğ’† , lugal-ene si-mash-giki "Kings of the country of Simashgi"), was an early dynasty of the ancient region of Elam, to the southeast of Babylonia, in approximately 2100-1900 BCE.
